channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Lede: Video Shows U.N. Inspectors Interviewing Survivors of Suspected Syrian Chemical Attack
item.description: Antigovernment activists posted video to YouTube that showed United Nations inspectors in blue helmets and body armor arriving at a cramped rebel clinic, where they interviewed witnesses and survivors of a suspected chemical attack.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK

item.title: Iran’s Pick for Nuclear Talks Carries Hope of Eased Tensions
item.description: Mohammad Javad Zarif seems near certain to lead Iran’s delegation in nuclear talks — further indications, analysts say, that the new leadership is serious about reducing tensions.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Iran's new moderate president, Hassan Rouhani, left, with the country’s new foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Official Denies Inquiry Into Egyptian Activists
item.description: Reports in the state news media over the weekend drew attention as evidence that the Egyptian government was broadening its crackdown on dissent.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Israeli Raid on Palestinian Camp Turns Deadly
item.description: The violent clash, which killed least three Palestinians, was the deadliest episode in the West Bank in months, and it underlined the region’s volatility in the midst of a new round of peace talks.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and SAID GHAZALI
item.media:description: Palestinians carry the body of Jihad Aslan during his funeral at the Qalandia refugee camp.

item.title: Kerry Says Chemical Arms Attack in Syria Is ‘Undeniable’
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry said Monday that the Obama administration would hold the Syrian government accountable for what he called a “moral obscenity” that had shocked the world’s conscience.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, ALAN COWELL and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: U.N. chemical weapons experts visited a hospital where wounded people affected by an apparent gas attack are being treated, in the Damascus suburb of Mouadamiya.

item.title: Lens Blog: A Show of Strength by Middle Eastern Women Photographers
item.description: An exhibit opening in Boston explores “complexities of identity,” showcasing works of art by female photographers in the Arab world, including Iran.
item.dc:creator: By KERRI MACDONALD

item.title: India Ink: Outside Mumbai, Reports of Rape Buried in Pages of Newspapers
item.description: The occurrence of a rape in Mumbai made it to the front pages of Indian newspapers, but reports of sexual assault elsewhere in the country found scant attention last week.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: People watching as youth demonstrate on Sunday against the gang rape of a photojournalist in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

item.title: India Ink: The Rape Suspect Who Slept on Sidewalks
item.description: The biography of Vijay Jadhav, one of the five men accused of the rape in Mumbai, is one of homelessness, unemployment, and petty crime.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: Police officers in plain clothes escorting one of the five suspects, center, in the gang rape of a photojournalist in Mumbai, Maharashtra on Monday.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: August 26
item.description: The 103rd anniversary of Mother Teresa’s birth was commemorated in Kolkata, West Bengal.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: The 103rd anniversary of Mother Teresa's birth was commemorated in Kolkata, West Bengal.

item.title: At War Blog: Remembering Iraq on an Indian Reservation
item.description: Nathan S. Webster asks why Lance Marottek, 25, returned to the Fort Peck Indian Reservation in northwestern Montana after five years in the Army.
item.dc:creator: By NATHAN S. WEBSTER
item.media:description: Pfc. Lance Marrotek during a Sons of Iraq payday in Tarmiyah, June 2008. The Awakening Councils, also known as the Sons of Iraq, were local groups, including former insurgents and Baathists, who turned against the insurgency and received pay, first from the Americans and then from the Iraqis.

item.title: Filipinos Stage Anticorruption Protest in Manila
item.description: The peaceful four-hour rally reflected growing anger over corruption, extortion and bribery on the part of government officials.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: Political Staging in Trial of Fallen China Official
item.description: As his trial ended Monday, Bo Xilai asserted that his wife and the prosecution’s other star witness, a former police chief, had a secret affair.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and JONATHAN ANSFIELD
item.media:description: The courthouse in the city of Jinan where the ousted Communist Party official Bo Xilai is standing trial on corruption and abuse of power charges.

item.title: India Ink: Being Adoor Gopalakrishnan
item.description: Profile of the Indian film director who has over the past four decades explored expansive themes through 11 feature films and 22 documentaries, many of which have won awards.
item.dc:creator: By SALIL TRIPATHI
item.media:description: Adoor Gopalakrishnan, an Indian film director, at the 10th Asian Film Festival held in Deauville, France, on Mar. 15, 2008.

item.title: Egypt Military Enlists Religion to Quell Ranks
item.description: Egyptian military leaders are worried about insubordination among the rank and file after members of the security forces killed hundreds of their fellow countrymen.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:credit: Ravy Shaker/El Shorouk Newspaper, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Lawyers for leaders of the Muslim Brotherhood who were arrested as part of a government crackdown over the past month appeared in court in Cairo on Sunday.

item.title: As Egyptians Ignore Curfew, Talk of a U.S.-Brotherhood Conspiracy
item.description: Among supporters of the military, which ousted Mohamed Morsi, there is a widespread view that the United States and the Muslim Brotherhood have a plan to destroy Egypt.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: A banner of President Obama with a salafist-styled beard reflected a common conspiracy theory.

item.title: Canadian Documents Suggest Shift on Pipeline
item.description: Papers released to an environmental group say Canada’s government once viewed Keystone XL as important to oil sands development, in contrast to a United States assessment.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Activist Running for Mayor of Moscow Is Briefly Detained
item.description: Aleksei A. Navalny was held by the police after staging a rally that attracted several thousand supporters.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: Surveillance Revelations Shake U.S.-German Ties
item.description: The issue is prompting not just a debate about privacy and data protection, but also demands from German officials that the Berlin-Washington security partnership be put on a new footing.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Colloredo Di Prato Journal: From Italy, a Vintage Redolent of Horrors
item.description: The Simon Wiesenthal Center has called on distributors to stop handling a line of Italian wines that carry labels that portray Hitler and sundry members of the Nazi hierarchy.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Laia Abril for the International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Vini Lunardelli uses labels depicting historical figures, including Adolf Hitler, on their wine bottles.

item.title: Heavy Casualties on Both Sides as Congo Soldiers Fight Rebels Near Eastern City
item.description: The front line is nine miles north of the eastern city of Goma, where Congolese soliders and United Nations troops have been battling M23 rebels since Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Expositions Can Benefit or Haunt Host Cities
item.description: Expo locations can enjoy an influx of jobs and tourism, but the costs of staging such an event can be staggering.
item.dc:creator: By GEORGI KANTCHEV
item.media:description: An electronically animated giant baby graced Spain’s pavilion at the Shanghai World Expo 2010, which cost $4.2 billion.

item.title: Dozens Killed in Attacks Across Iraq
item.description: The attacks by insurgents are part of a wave of killing that is the country’s worst bloodshed since 2008 and has called into question the security forces’ ability to protect the country.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: At Least 5 Die as Train Derails in Mexico
item.description: A cargo train carrying at least 250 Central American migrants heading to the United States derailed Sunday in Southern Mexico, killing at least 5 people and injuring 16.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Prayer Plaza in Jerusalem for Both Sexes Ignites Uproar
item.description: Israeli officials unveiled a plaza where men and women can pray together. But the move was denounced as discriminatory by the main group that has protested the rules at the holy site.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Political Staging in Trial of Fallen China Official
item.description: What has most captivated ordinary Chinese — thanks to headlines in major state media outlets — is a mountain of testimony that depicts Mr. Bo as the archetypal corrupt official.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and JONATHAN ANSFIELD
